descriptionHTML: Women with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch Syndrome, who are at higher risk for endometrial cancer, may consider annual screening via pelvic ultrasound, starting between the ages of 30 and 35.

Individuals with Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch Syndrome, who are at higher risk for gastric cancer, may benefit from screening with oesophago-gastro duodenoscopy (OGD), starting from age 30 to 35 years. A frequency of 2 to 3 years is recommended, based on the individual's risk factors.

High-risk individuals should perform either a hepatobiliary system ultrasound (US HBS) or a Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP) test on a six monthly basis. There is no definite recommended age to start surveillance although local statistics show that liver cancer incidence starts to increase from the 40 to 49 age group.

High-risk individuals aged between 55 to 74 can perform low-dose CT screening on an annual basis. But this should be balanced with the unnecessary exposure to radiation, financial costs of CT screening, and a high rate of false positive findings.
riskGroups: Smoked â‰¥ 30 pack years and still smoking or quit less than 15 years ago

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform a tumor marker test for nose cancer (EBV-EA-EBNA-1) and a nasopharyngoscopy. The tumor marker test alone without the endoscopy is not recommended.
BRCA carriers can consider a transvaginal pelvic ultrasound. However, it can result in unnecessary surgeries with no clear mortality benefit.

Men who are between 50 to 70 years of age, with an estimated life expectancy of more than 10 years, may be offered screening with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) tumor marker, after a discussion of both the potential benefits and harms associated with prostate cancer screening.
riskGroups: First-degree relative with prostate cancer before age 65 years

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform a screening with abdominal ultrasound.
riskGroups: Men aged 65 to 75 years who have ever smoked

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform a screening via a brain MRI.
riskGroups: Two or more first-degree relatives with intracranial aneurysms

descriptionHTML:
High-risk individuals may wish to perform any of the following screenings after a discussion of both the potential benefits and harms.

  • ECG
  • hsCRP
  • Apolipoprotein A and B
  • Coronary artery calcium score (CACS)
  • Treadmill stress test
High-risk individuals can undergo the ankle brachial index (ABI), a simple non-invasive test.
riskGroups: Aged 50 to 70 years with both hypertension and hyperlipidaemia

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can undergo the urine PCR test or a cervical or urethral swab for PCR.

High-risk individuals can perform the Hepatitis B screen. All pregnant women should be tested for Hepatitis B during early antenatal visit. There is good evidence that universal prenatal screening for HBV infection substantially reduces prenatal transmission of HBV and the subsequent development of chronic HBV infection.
riskGroups: Travelers from countries where Hepatitis B is endemic
Potential exposure via blood, sexual activity, or other body fluid

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform the Hepatitis C screen.
riskGroups: Travelers from countries where Hepatitis C is endemic
Potential exposure via blood, sexual activity, or other body fluid

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform the HIV screen. All pregnant women should be tested for HIV, since steps can be taken to prevent viral spread to the unborn baby and during delivery.
riskGroups: Potential exposure via blood, sexual activity, or other body fluid

lifestyle: Active sexual activity with multiple partners

descriptionHTML: High-risk individuals can perform the syphilis enzyme immunoassay or other tests such as TPPA or TPHA. All pregnant women are recommended to screen for syphilis due to the high risk of infant morbidity and mortality.
Tuberculosis is an airborne infectious disease that can be spread when patients cough or sneeze. Individuals with close contact to existing patients can perform the Mantoux test or a chest X-ray.
riskGroups: Close contacts of infectious TB patients

descriptionHTML: Screening is recommended for all pregnant women because anemia increases the risk of a premature birth, as well as the likelihood of a low birth weight baby and postpartum depression. Anemia can be screened via the a full blood count test.

Screening for albuminuria, a type of kidney disorder, should be done annually after the diagnosis of diabetes (after 5 years for Type 1, immediately for Type 2), via the a urine test for microalbumin/creatinine ratio.

Other individuals at risk of kidney disease should also undergo kidney function tests or urine analysis.
riskGroups: Aged 50 years and older who smoke

descriptionHTML: For females, the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool (OSTA) for postmenopausal Asian women should be used as a risk assessment tool first before deciding on whether a bone mass density (BMD) measurement should be offered.
riskGroups: Postmenopausal Asian women with a high score for the OSTA

descriptionHTML:
High-risk individuals can perform the thyroid function test (TFT).

Additionally, for obese individuals, hypothyroidism may be a potential cause.

Pregnant women who have diabetes or adrenal disease may develop goitre during pregnancy, potentially causing mental retardation in the baby. TFT should be performed once early on during pregnancy.

All patients diagnosed with diabetes require regular visual acuity assessment and eye examinations by trained personnel to screen for diabetic retinopathy. Type 1 diabetic patients should be examined 3 to 5 years after diagnosis of diabetes, and at least once yearly subsequently. Type 2 diabetic patients should have an ocular assessment at the time of diagnosis and at least once yearly subsequently.
